Literature Review: Carbonate clumped isotope thermometry has emerged as a powerful tool for reconstructing mineral growth temperatures in surface and subsurface environments. The technique relies on the measurement of clumped isotopic values, Δ47, Δ48, and Δ638, which reflect the thermodynamic preference of heavy C and O isotopes to clump or bond with each other. This approach has been extensively developed over the past two decades, yielding a mature temperature proxy with an external precision of 1–2°C (2 standard error of the mean) across a wide temperature range of 0.5 to 1,100°C.
